Measurements of sin 2α/φ2 from B → ππ, ρπ and ρρ modes.
Adrian Bevan
Department of Physics
Liverpool University
Liverpool, United Kingdom
(from the BABAR Collaboration.)
Talk given at Flavor Physics and CP Violation, 4th − 9th October 2004, Daegu, Korea.

B meson decays involving b → u transitions are sensitive to the unitarity triangle angle α
(or φ2 ). The BABAR and Belle experiments have studied B-meson decays to ππ, ρπ and ρρ
final states. It is possible to combine these measurements to constrain α with a precision
of O(10◦ ) and a central value of approximately 100 degrees. These results are consistent
with Standard Model expectations.

1

Introduction

This is a summary of the experimental constraint on α obtained by the B-factories from B
meson decays involving b → u transitions. The final states of interest for these studies are
B → hh, where h = ρ, π. CP Violation (CPV) in the Standard Model of particle physics
(SM) is described by a single complex phase. Interference between direct decay and decay after
B 0 -B 0 mixing results in a time-dependent decay-rate asymmetry between B 0 and B 0 decaying
to h+ h− that is sensitive to the CKM [1] angle α ≡ arg [−Vtd Vtb∗ /Vud Vub∗ ]. The presence of
loop (penguin) contributions introduces additional phases that can shift the experimentally
measurable parameter αeff away from the value of α. In the presence of penguin contributions
αeff = α + δαpenguin . The CKM angle β is well known and consistent with SM predictions.
Any constraint on α constitutes a new test of the SM description of quark mixing and CPV in
B-meson decays. Any significant deviation from SM expectation would be a clear indication of
new physics. The SM prediction for α are [95 ± 9]◦ from [2] and [98 ± 16]◦ [3].
There are two classes of measurement that the B-factories are pursuing, the main goal is to
use SU(2) relations to relate different hh final states and limit δαpenguin in each of the modes
B 0 (B 0 ) → π + π − , B 0 → ρ+ π − and B 0 (B 0 ) → ρ+ ρ− . In some cases only weak constraints on
α are obtained when using SU(2) analysis and one must use a model dependent approach to
obtain a significant result.
Experimental results are quoted with statistical errors preceding systematic errors unless
otherwise stated.

For initial measurements of α, one can safely neglect electroweak penguin contributions to
the isospin analysis as these are a small correction to α [7]. Some estimates of the effect of
SU(2) symmetry breaking exist [8], where any correction is estimated to be much less than 10◦ .

One should note that the Belle measurement of B 0 (B 0 ) → π + π − constitutes an observation
of mixing-induced CPV in this decay at a level of 5.2σ, and evidence for direct CPV at a level
of 3.2σ. This is the second observation of CPV in B-meson decays and is illustrated in Figure 1
. The BABAR data do not support this conclusion, and the discrepancy between the two
experiments is more than 3σ. One must wait for a significant increase in statistics from both
experiments to see if the results of the experiments become more compatible.
The ππ isospin analysis is limited by the value of B(B 0 (B 0 ) → π 0 π 0 ). Unfortunately this
is neither large enough to provide sufficient statistics with the current data set to perform
a precision measurement of αef f − α , nor small enough to enable a strong bound on this
quantity. BABAR have performed an isospin analysis resulting in |αef f − α| < 35◦ (90% C.L.).
It is possible to derive model dependent constraints on α, as done by the Belle Collaboration;
90 < α < 146◦ [10] (90% C.L.) using [11].

B → ρπ

The decays B → ρπ can be analysed in two different ways. The more straight forward approach
is to cut away interference regions of the π + π − π 0 DP and analyse the regions in the vicinity
of ρ resonances. This is called the Quasi-2-body approach (Q2B) and it avoids the need to
5

 understand the interference regions. The drawback of the Q2B method is that one looses
statistical power by cutting on the DP. A corollory of this is that one requires more statistics
than the B-factories currently have in order to get a significant constraint from the pentagon
isospin analysis. The alternative is to perform an analysis of the B → π + π − π 0 DP, accounting
for the interference between intersecting ρ resonance bands and other resonant structure. Both
of these approaches have been studied by BABAR [18]. Belle has performed a Q2B analysis of
ρπ [19], and the first time-dependent DP analysis has been performed by BABAR [20].

(Figure 3 shows the corresponding confidence level plot for α). This result is self consistent as
the strong phase differences and amplitudes are determined solely from the structure of the DP.
The unique aspect of this result is that there is only a single solution between 0 and 180◦ , thus
a two fold ambiguity in the ρη plane. As a result this measurement is an important constraint
on alpha, ancillary to that of the BABAR B 0 → ρρ analysis.
It is possible to derive a model dependent constraint on alpha from these data. As shown
by Gronau and Zupan [21]. One can make several assumptions, including (i) the relative strong
phase differences between tree level contributions for ρ+ π − and ρ− π + being less than 90◦ (ii)
SU(3) being exact for penguin amplitudes (iii) neglecting Electroweak penguins (iv) neglecting
annihilation and exchange diagrams to derive a constraint on α. SU(3) breaking effects are
estimated in this model using CLEO, BABAR and Belle data. When doing this Belle obtain
α = (102 ± 11expt ± 15model )◦ . Gronau and Zupan compute the corresponding result for the
BABAR analysis as (93 ± 4expt ± 15model )◦ . There are other models proposed in the literature,
for example [22].

8

Summary

In the past year the B-factories have made significant progress towards a precision measurement
of the unitarity triangle angle α, only relying on SU(2) symmetry. The dominant constraint
comes from B → ρρ decays [14], which has a four-fold ambiguity in the ρη plane. The BABAR
analysis of B → π + π − π 0 decays represents the first time-dependent CP analysis. Inclusion
of the interference regions of the DP enables one to measure strong phase differences between
amplitudes contributing to the final state; In turn this enables one to derive a self consistent
constraint of α with a two fold ambiguity in the ρη plane. One can also employ models to
further constrain α as has been discussed herein.
